title: DOM
definition: The Document Object Model (DOM) is an interface for interacting with web documents. It provides a hierarchical tree-like structure of objects that represent the elements and content of a web page, including HTML. Developers use JavaScript to interact with and manipulate these objects, enabling dynamic control and modification of web content.

title: Client
definition: Typically, client in web development refers to the software, or web browser used to access a website or web app such as Google chrome. These make requests to servers to get certain data or resourses.

title: Server
definition: A server is a way of storing or managing data and other resourses through a physical computer (hardware) or service (software). Clients, most often web broswers, can make fetch and other requests to the server to get the appropriate resourses needed. Software includes virtual, cloud based or database servers.

title: Client-side/ Server-side
definition: 'Client-side' refers to the underlying code and processes, such as HTML, CSS and JS, that create the visual and dynamic experience for a user. 'Server-side' in the same way means the underlying code and processes, such as Django, which run on the server. These respond to client requests.

title: Frontend
definition: A general term for the part of a web application that a user ineracts with. A visual representation of a website such as images, buttons, navigation that make up the design and functionality.

title: Backend
definition: The backend refers to the entire server-side aspect of a web application that the user does not directly interact with. Including the code that handles client requests, the database, security, API's and more.

title: Angle bracket uses
definition: These are used to define and enclose HTML tags, an essential feature for web development. Also, in JS they can be used as comparison operators, for instance greater than or less than.

title: CPU
definition: The primary component of a computer. It executes tasks by processing instructions from computer programs. Often referred to as the 'brain', it handles data, runs software and responds to requests made by the user.

title: API
definition: An API, conceptually, is a set of rules and protocols that define the methods and data formats required for applications to request and exchange information. For example, a web API uses the HTTP protocol to specify methods like 'POST' and 'GET' and often utilizes data formats like JSON to transfer data between clients and servers.

title: CDN
definition: A Content Delivery Network (CDN) is a network of distributed servers located around the world. It caches and serves copies of data, including images and other content, from the origin server to various geographic locations. When a client requests this data, the CDN automatically delivers it from the edge server closest to the client, improving efficiency and reducing load times.

title: XSS
definition: Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) is a type of security vulnerability in web applications where attackers attempt to inject malicious code, often in the form of JavaScript, into the application. If the application fails to properly sanitize or validate user inputs, these injected scripts can execute in the browsers of other users accessing the affected page. This can lead to various malicious actions such as redirecting users to harmful websites, stealing sensitive information like session cookies, or performing unauthorized actions on behalf of the user.

title: CMS
definition: A CMS, or content management system, is a software application that can be run either locally or online, used for creating, managing, and publishing digital content to the internet. It simplifies the process of web development, making it a preferred choice those with technical expertise. CMSs support various content types, including text, images, videos, and documents. Popular CMS examples include WordPress and Squarespace.

title: GUI
definition: A GUI, or graphical user interface, employs visual elements like buttons, icons, and menus to provide a user-friendly and intuitive way to navigate and interact with software or devices. Examples of GUIs include ATM screens, Google Chrome, and Windows. In contrast, a CLI (command-line interface) relies on text-based commands, as seen in tools like Git Bash.

title: JSON
definition: JavaScript Object Notation is a user-friendly data format used in software development. It's easy for both humans to read and write and for machines to parse or generate. JSON consists of key-value pairs and is commonly used for data exchange between servers and clients, often converted into a programming language like JavaScript, using a function like response.JSON().

title: FTP
definition: FTP, or File Transfer Protocol, is a set of rules  for how files should be shared over a network between client and server. It defines how users upload, download and manage files on remote servers. FTP has been replaced often by other protocols such as SFTP or FTPS, as the data is not encrypted and therefore less secure. However, where security is less of an issue, FTP is still used - for instance in legacy systems.

title: SFTP
definition: SFTP, or Secure File Transfer Protocol, is a network protocol like FTP, but more secure. It encrypts and authenticates data to protect it during transit using SSH keys.

title: MVC
definition: MVC is a software design pattern, often used in web development, that seperates an application into three components. The Model retrieves and handles data, the View presents the data to the user and the Controller recieves the input and processes it. MVT uses templates instead.

title: PWA
definition: A Progressive Web Application uses HTML, CSS and JS to create user friendly experiences that mimic native apps througha a web browser. These can be downloaded and added to a home screen, or accessed through a browser such as Google Chrome.

title: SDK
definition: A Software Development Kit contains tools for developers to use when building an application, which simplify or expedite the process. In web development, this may be Stripe's javascript functions or API's, for a purpose like handling payments. Though it could include other resourses like libraries, sample code and more. The predefined nature of the tools speeds up development as you don't have to write all the code yourself.

title: SEO
definition: Search Engine Optimization (SEO) encompasses a range of strategies and methods aimed at enhancing organic website traffic, excluding paid means. These techniques involve optimizing content elements like keywords, titles, and metadata. This optimization aims to improve a website's visibility on search engine results pages (SERPs), potentially leading to higher rankings and increased prominence in search results on platforms like Google.

title: URL
definition: A Uniform Resource Locator is an address of a resource on the Internet, typically built up of a protocol, domain, and paths or parameters.

title: XML
definition: XML is a markup language used to store and transport data in a human and machine readable format. Like HTML, XML uses tags to define the structure of the data, focusing on describing the data rather then diplaying it. The X stands for extensible, meaning tags to not need to be predefined and one can create as they please, which is a distinguishing feature of XML.

title: TDD
definition: Test Driven Development is a software development approach where tests are written before writing the code. This is to drive the design and development of the code through testing. First a test is written, then observed to fail, before code is written to pass the test. Once the code passes it is refactored and then the cycle repeats.

title: BDD
definition: Behaviour Driven Development is a software development approach that encourages collaboration between developers, quality assurance and non-technical business stakeholders. It defines what a system should do based on scenarios and examples written in a natural language called Gherkin syntax. This aims to bridge the gap between the technical understanding of a developer and business goals and provide clarity. There are executible specifications contained within to ensure the system's behaviour meets the desired outcomes of all parties.

title: SVG
definition: Scalable Vector Graphics is an image format that is vector based, meaning it can be scaled to any size without losing quality, as, rather than being based on pixels, it is written in a text based XML-like format. They are commonly used for logos, icons or illustrations and can be edited in the code, for instance to change it's background color.
